header.title: HTTP User Media Streams
header.abstract: This specification defines a payload format for the ingestion and egress of media streams for music and other media collaborations using WebRTC-based ingestion/egress.

section1.p: While WebRTC specifies the usage of SDPs [RFC8866] and an Offer/Answer model [RFC3264] for creating connections, WebRTC does not define the precise signaling protocols over which SDPs should be exchanged [RFC8825]. In order to establish a WebRTC session between two WebRTC entities, a signaling protocol is usually used to exchange SDPs
With HTTP/S applications, WHIP and WHEP have been proposed as simple protocols to ingest and egress media streams using WebRTC.

This specification provides the means to do likewise in XMPP for communicating user media streams using WebRTC-based ingestion/egress. The WebRTC SDP payload format is transported using IQ stanzas which map directly to WHIP and WHEP REST endpoints.

This specification does not prescribe a method for the security, discovery, publishing and subscription of published media stream keys. It is assumed that this will be achieved with other XMPP mechanisms like &xep0060; or &xep0482; for example.

ul.li: Be as easy to implement as possible. This is grounded on the idea that most XMPP implementation programming languages already have HTTP libraries available.
Usable with WebRTC-based broadcasting providers that have no XMPP integration.
Usable with XMPP client applications that may have no HTTP/S access to the WebRTC-based ingestion/egress service.
Anyone who knows the WHIP and WHEP REST Endpoints SHOULD be able to access them as well.

WHIP and WHEP media streams should map directly to XMPP Jingle sessions with uni-directional media streams. &xep0482; with a stream key URI and a Jingle session identifier SHOULD be referencing the same media stream.

section2.p: The entity advertises support for WebRTC-based ingestion/egress, as specified by this protocol, by including the "urn:xmpp:whip:0" namespace, as well as "urn:xmpp:whep:0" namespaces in its service discovery information features as specified in in &xep0030;.

If the entity can push ice candidates patches from the WebRTC-based ingestion/egress, it SHOULD include 'urn:xmpp:whip:ice:0' and 'urn:xmpp:whep:ice:0' namespaces. If the WebRTC-based egress supports extensions, then it SHOULD also include the 'urn:xmpp:whep:ext:0' namespace.
If the entity can transcribe voice into text from an ingested media stream, it SHOULD include the 'urn:xmpp:whip:transcribe:0' namespace.

example.caption: Client sends service discovery request to server
Server replies to service discovery request and reports capability for WebRTC-based ingestion, egress, extensions, ice candidate trickles and voice to text transcription.

section2.example: <iq from='shakespeare.lit' to='juliet@capulet.lit/producer' id='disco_01' type='result'> <query xmlns='http://jabber.org/protocol/disco#info'> <identity category='server' type='im' name='Openfire Server'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whip:0'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whip:ice:0'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whip:transcribe:0'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whep:0'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whep:ice:0'/> <feature var='urn:xmpp:whep:ext:0'/> </query> </iq>

section2.topic: User requests server to ingest a media stream
section2.p: A sample protocol flow to ingest a media session from the client. The client MUST provide a WHIP SDP offer and a stream key for the ingest. If the client has discovered that the server can transcribe voice into text, it can make a request using the transcribe attribute.

example.caption: Client sends a WHIP SDP offer of a media stream to server and requests for voice audio to text transcription

section2.example: <iq from='juliet@capulet.lit/producer' id='ih28sx61' type='set'> <whip xmlns='urn:xmpp:whip:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61' transcribe='true'> <sdp> ...... SDP OFFER </sdp> </whip> </iq>
section2.p: The server responds with a IQ result that contains a WHIP SDP answer.
The server MAY respond with an error if the request fails. In addition, the WHIP endpoint entity MAY inform the requester about the reason for the failure.

Depending on how the WHIP service is configured, the server MAY include a complete SDP answer including ICE candidates or a partial SDP without ICE candidates and later push a patched WHIP SDP with ICE candidates as they trickle in.

example.caption: The server responds with a complete or partial WHIP SDP answer for the client

section2.example: <iq to='juliet@capulet.lit/producer' id='ih28sx61' from='shakespeare.lit' type='result'> <whip xmlns='urn:xmpp:whip:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61' url="https://capulet.lit/media/juliet-ih28sx61.mp4"> <sdp> ...... SDP ANSWER </sdp> </whip> </iq>

example.caption: The server pushes a patched WHIP SDP with ICE candidates

section2.example: <iq to='juliet@shakespeare.lit/producer' id='87645fg23' from='shakespeare.lit' type='set'> <whip xmlns='urn:xmpp:whip:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <sdp> ...... SDP PATCH </sdp> </whip> </iq>

example.caption: Alternative response by the server if media streaming is restricted for the requestor

section2.example: <iq to='juliet@shakespeare.lit/producer' id='87645fg23' from='shakespeare.lit' type='error'> <whip xmlns='urn:xmpp:whip:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <error type='modify'> <not-acceptable xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-stanzas'/> <text xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-stanzas'>Streaming is in use</text> </error> </whip> </iq>

example.caption: The server streams transcribed text to the client from voice audio in the ingested media stream

section2.example: <message to='juliet@shakespeare.lit/producer' id='msg1' from='shakespeare.lit' type='chat'> <transcribe xmlns='urn:xmpp:whip:transcribe:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61' /> <body> ....... Text </body> </iq>

section2.topic: Client shares the media stream key with another user
section2.p: The client is responsible for publishing the stream key to all users permitted to egress the media stream with any suitable XMPP mechanism. In this example, &xep0482; is used.

example.caption: The media publishing user invites another user to egress the media stream

section2.example: <message to='romeo@example.com' id='id1' from='juliet@capulet.lit/producer' type='chat'> <invite xmlns='urn:xmpp:call-invites:0'> <external uri='whep:juliet-ih28sx61' /> </invite> </message>

example.caption: The invited user sends an WHEP SDP offer to egress the media stream

section2.example: <iq from='romeo@shakespeare.lit/consumer' id='6338Vbrhrl' type='set'> <whep xmlns='urn:xmpp:whep:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <sdp> ...... SDP OFFER </sdp> </whep> </iq>

example.caption: The server responds with an WHEP SDP answer for the client and the available WHEP extensions supported

section2.example: <iq to='romeo@shakespeare.lit/consumer' id='6338Vbrhrl' from='shakespeare.lit' type='result'> <whep xmlns='urn:xmpp:whep:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <sdp> ...... SDP ANSWER </sdp> <exts> <ext xmlns='urn:ietf:params:whep:ext:core:server-sent-events' /> <ext xmlns='urn:ietf:params:whep:ext:core:layer' /> </exts> </whep> </iq>

example.caption: The server pushes a WHEP simulcast layers server-sent event

section2.example: <iq to='romeo@shakespeare.lit/consumer' id='3947254qxcf' from='shakespeare.lit' type='set'> <whep xmlns='urn:xmpp:whep:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <ext xmlns='urn:ietf:params:whep:ext:core:server-sent-events'> ...... JSON PAYLOAD </ext> </whep> </iq>

<iq from='romeo@shakespeare.lit/consumer' id='8453sf42' type='set'> <whep xmlns='urn:xmpp:whep:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <ext xmlns='urn:ietf:params:whep:ext:core:layer'> ...... JSON PAYLOAD </ext> </whep> </iq>
section2.p: Similiar to the WHIP service, the WHEP service may respond with a complete SDP including ICE candidates or may push a patched WHEP SDP with ICE candidates as they trickle in

example.caption: The server pushes a patched WHEP SDP with ICE candidates

section2.example: <iq to='romeo@shakespeare.lit/consumer' id='54398hdg21' from='shakespeare.lit' type='set'> <whep xmlns='urn:xmpp:whep:0' key='juliet-ih28sx61'> <sdp> ...... SDP PATCH </sdp> </whep> </iq>
